In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other 
status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since 2006, the Government of Viet Nam has discussed with the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) the need to take steps to 
protect rural infrastructure from the anticipated effects of climate change. In support of this need, 
the Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF) of the Global Environment Facility (GEF) invited 
UNDP and ADB to submit a proposal for a parallel financed technical assistance (TA) project 
entitled Promoting Climate Resilient Rural Infrastructure in Northern Mountain Provinces of 
Viet Nam.1 The SCCF/GEF requested ADB to take the lead role in preparing the TA project. The 
SCCF/GEF will provide a total of $3.4 million for the TA project. The Ministry of Agriculture and 
Rural Development (MARD) will execute it in concert with the implementation of the ADB loan 
funded Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Development Project in Northern Mountain Provinces 
(SRIDP).2 The SRIDP project management will be expanded to cover the TA project.3 
2.  The TA project will have common geographic targeting and consist of five components. 
UNDP will carry out four components estimated to cost $1.4 million, over a 4-year period.4 The 
ADB-administered  component  is  estimated  to  cost  $2  million  and  is  prepared  as  capacity 
development TA.5 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The TA proposal was 
thoroughly reviewed with MARD in January 2011. A memorandum of understanding for the ADB 
component was signed with MARD on 21 January 2011. ADB submitted the TA proposal to the 
SCCF/GEF in February 2011. Approval for the TA project was received from the SCCF/GEF on 
23 April 2012. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Since  the  mid-1990s,  the  government  has  been  engaged  in  a  program  of  rural 
infrastructure development with funding from ADB, the World Bank, the government’s own 
resources, and other development partners. The positive results of this program to date have 
contributed (along with other factors) to improvements in the standard of living of a large portion 
of the rural population and a decline in poverty from 53% in 1993 to 16% in 2008.  
 
4.  Viet  Nam  is  one  of  the  most  disaster-prone  countries  in  the  world.  It  suffers  from 
typhoons, floods, droughts, and landslides. Flooding and landslides triggered by typhoons are 
the most prevalent natural disasters.6 Many of Viet Nam’s rivers, especially in mountainous 
areas, are short and steep. Heavy rainfall in their upper catchment areas thus produces intense, 
short duration flash floods that frequently occur without warning, taking lives and destroying 
infrastructure, houses, and farmland in their path. From 1995 to 2005, storms caused 6,000 
deaths, destroyed 320,000 houses, and resulted in capital stock loss of more than $2.5 billion, 
                                                
1 The definition of parallel financed projects is provided in ADB. 2003. Cofinancing. Operations Manual. OM E1/OP. 
(Appendix 1, Section A). 
2 ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the Socialist 
Republic of Viet Nam for the Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Development Project in Northern Mountain Provinces. 
Manila. 
3 The TA was originally attached to the SRIDP, but at the time of circulation of the SRIDP for Board consideration 
(September 2010), SCCF/GEF funding was not confirmed. Consequently, the TA needed to be detached from the 
SRIDP and processed as a standalone TA. 
4 The four UNDP components are (i) mainstreaming of climate risk reduction into policy formulation and infrastructure 
development planning, (ii) capacity development to increase understanding about current and emerging climate 
risks and to promote the use of climate resilience techniques during local planning activities, (iii) dissemination of 
lessons learned and best practices, and (iv) project management. 
5 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 June 2011. 
6 On the average, four to six typhoons hit Viet Nam each year and batter the eastern seaboard over much of its    
3,260-kilometer length, causing extensive damage to a wide range of rural infrastructure: bridges, roads, irrigation 
works, market places, and schools.

2 
 
representing about 5% of gross annual capital formation.7 These problems are expected to 
worsen with increasing climate fluctuation and intensification of climate events. In response, the 
government launched the National Target Program to Respond to Climate Change. 
 
5.  The ADB-funded investments in rural infrastructure mostly consist of roads, irrigation, 
markets, water supply, and post-harvest facilities. Rural infrastructure is particularly vulnerable 
to damage caused by climate change-attributed impacts. The most potentially damaging effect 
is increased intensities and duration of rainfall causing increases in the volume and velocity of 
surface water movement. This can cause severe erosion, leading to rural infrastructure damage. 
The damage results in high maintenance and rehabilitation costs as well as the loss of benefits 
while rural infrastructure remains in poor condition. At present, few mainstreamed measures are 
practiced in Viet Nam that can affordably prevent or mitigate these impacts.   
 
6.  There are, however, a range of engineering options to counter the anticipated impacts of 
climate  change  on  rural  infrastructure.  Options  range  from  technically  sophisticated  civil 
engineering approaches to far less costly bioengineering approaches. Selection of the most 
appropriate option needs to be done within a susceptibility–hazard–risk framework.8 For rural 
infrastructure, where the risk of failure is usually less catastrophic in comparison to that of major 
infrastructure, solutions need to be low-cost and maximize local inputs.  
 
7.  Bioengineering  approaches  are  low-cost  techniques  that  involve  the  protection  of 
exposed earth surfaces and structures through the use of live vegetation complemented by 
simple  civil  works.  These  measures  provide  a  low-cost  means  of  supplementing  current 
technical  standards  to  prevent  soil  erosion  and  to  reduce  slope  instability  in  hilly  areas. 
Bioengineering entails an element of carbon capture, and thus contributes to counter the causes 
of climate change. This approach is highly labor-intensive and can provide employment and 
livelihood opportunities for rural people, increasing their capacities to cope with the impacts of 
climate change. The application of bioengineering approaches could be quickly scaled up. 
 
8.  There is a need to demonstrate and mainstream measures that can be taken to reduce 
anticipated climate change impacts on rural infrastructure. The demonstrations should illustrate 
the value of low-cost, climate-resilient techniques selected according to specific site conditions. 
The techniques should be demonstrated in provinces that represent different environments and 
anticipated  climate  change  effects.  Demonstrations  are  needed  on  different  kinds  of  rural 
infrastructure such as roads, irrigation structures, and river embankments. This will enable the 
compilation of a range of environments and infrastructure to match with an array of appropriate 
approaches.  Knowledge  dissemination  and  communication  strategy  and  action  plans  are 
needed to guide the flow of information about the demonstrations to the stakeholders. 
 
9.  The demonstrations should seek to optimize the potential social benefits, particularly for 
the poor and for women. They should rely on local resources that can be sustainably sourced 
from nearby communities. Careful selection and use of materials—such as specific plants that 
can be used for food, animal fodder, or medicinal purposes—will enhance the interests of local 
people in maintaining the condition of the sites in the long term. Construction or landscaping 
operations should be designed optimizing labor-based approaches to provide local employment 
opportunities.9 
 
                                                
7 World Bank. 2005. Project Appraisal Document on a Proposed Credit to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for a 
Natural Disaster Risk Management Project. Washington, DC. 
8 Susceptibility refers to the relative potential of failure; hazard defines the size and probability of an event; and risk 
combines hazard and the value of the assets at risk and their vulnerability to an event in order to define damage. 
9 ADB. 2009. The Economics of Climate Change in Southeast Asia: A Regional Review. Manila.

3 
 
10.  ADB’s Strategy 2020 identifies: (i) infrastructure; and (ii) environment, including climate 
change, as two of ADB’s five core operational areas.10 Rehabilitation of rural infrastructure has 
been a component of ADB’s lending program in Viet Nam through the past three country 
strategies and continues to be a component of the draft country partnership strategy, 2011–
2015 lending pipeline. The Agriculture, Natural Resources and Environment’s  Assessment, 
Strategy and Roadmap identifies two interrelated priorities: (i) enhanced rural productivity, which 
includes  improving  productive  rural  infrastructure;  and  (ii)  environmental  sustainability  and 
climate change resilience. The measures envisioned in the TA conform to these ADB policy and 
strategic priorities. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be improved climate resilience of rural infrastructure. Indicators 
of the impact are (i) increased use of climate resilient rural infrastructure approaches (from 0% 
to at least 70% by December 2020); and (ii) deterioration rates of the demonstration sites are 
lower than those of the control sites (75% lower by December 2020). 
 
12.   The outcome of the TA will be effective climate-resilience measures mainstreamed into 
the  MARD  rural  infrastructure  program.  The  approaches  developed—including  promising 
modifications, alternatives, and lessons learned—will be utilized by MARD rural infrastructure 
investments as standard practice in 100% of new ADB-financed projects by the end of the TA. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will have the following outputs: (i) identification of low-cost climate-proofing 
measures suitable for rural infrastructure in northern Viet Nam; (ii) demonstration of climate 
change resilient techniques in the provinces of Bac Kan and Son La on two rural roads, one 
irrigation  scheme,  and  one  river  embankment; 11 (iii)  establishment  of  a  trained  cadre  of 
technical personnel familiar with the protection measures; (iv) preparation of recommendations 
for the integration of the demonstrated approaches into  training curricula, standard design 
procedures,  and  contract  specifications;  and  (v)  identification  of  climate  change  risks  and 
vulnerabilities, and the potential for applying the measures used in the demonstrations for 
strengthening the resilience of nearby communities. 
 
14.  Key assumptions include the following: (i) MARD will carry out further pilot testing under 
different conditions—to be able to adapt the approaches to the wide range of environmental 
conditions  found  in  Viet  Nam,  and  (ii)  demonstrations  under  the  TA  are  successful  and 
convincing.12  
 
15.  Identified  risks  include  the  following:  (i)  MARD  fails  to  continue  monitoring  the 
demonstration and control sites after completion of the TA, (ii) actual climate change impacts 
are outside the assumed envelope at TA inception, (iii) demonstration results are undermined 
by  factors  outside  of  the  TA  control  (this  could  include  changes  in  land  use  within  the 
demonstration sites’ areas of influence), (iv) conservative views within MARD and the provincial 
departments of agriculture and rural development cause resistance to changes in practice (more

time and additional demonstration may be required to convince stakeholders), and (v) the 
project time of duration may be limited to adapt unfamiliar techniques to the specific conditions 
of the demonstration sites. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The government has requested UNDP to finance and administer $1,400,000 equivalent 
and ADB to finance and administer $2,000,000 equivalent (the TA). The TA project will be 
financed on a grant basis by the SCCF/GEF. The government will provide counterpart support 
in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space,  the  cost  of  long-term  monitoring  of  the 
demonstrations, and the costs of any changes to standards and construction manuals in order 
to incorporate the results of the demonstrations and other in-kind contributions (Appendix 2 
contains the cost estimates and financing plan). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MARD  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA  project.  MARD  will  take  on  this 
responsibility within the context of its mandated responsibilities in the National Target Program 
to Respond to Climate Change framework. The SRIDP central project management unit (CPMU) 
will be the implementing agency for the TA project. The CPMU director will be responsible for 
coordinating all field activities and institutional aspects among the government organizations, 
UNDP,  ADB,  and  the  SRIDP.  UNDP  will  provide  support  for  the  incremental  SRIDP 
management costs associated with the TA project. A deputy director to the SRIDP director will 
be responsible for managing the UNDP components and for coordinating the ADB TA.  
 
18.  MARD has implemented a range of rural infrastructure projects since the early 1990s.13 
All completed projects have been assessed by ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department as 
successful; and ongoing projects, despite some start-up delays, are generally on track for 
successful completion. The SRIDP project preparatory TA14 carried out detailed assessments 
endorsing MARD’s implementation capacities. The activities of the TA will be synchronized with 
the SRIDP to avoid implementation delays.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a 3-year period from September 2012 to August 2015. 
ADB will undertake engagement of consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The estimated consulting services input is 
80 person-months (25 international person-months and 55 national person-months). ADB will 
select (i) a consulting firm (23 international person-months and 55 national person-months) 
using quality- and cost-based selection (90:10)15 and a full technical proposal, and (ii) individual 
consultants (up to 2 person-months). The consulting services will consist of (i) international 
expertise in civil engineering, bioengineering, and geotechnical engineering; technical training; 
climate change adaptation; and social development; and (ii) national expertise in agricultural

engineering, agronomy/forestry, technical training, civil engineering, meteorology/ hydrology, 
gender, and indigenous peoples. The outline terms of reference for the consulting firm package 
are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  To supplement the services of the consulting firm and to allow for flexibility of inputs that 
are not yet foreseen, an allocation for 2 person-months (international) will not form part of the 
initial consulting services package tendered through quality- and cost-based selection. ADB will 
likely mobilize these consultants individually as needed.16 
 
21.  Civil works for the demonstration sites will be undertaken via a subcontract funded 
through the consultants’ contract. Equipment and materials to be financed by the TA will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). On completion of the TA project, equipment will become the property of the government 
and participating local institutions and/or communities. Disbursements under the TA will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). 
 
22.  The TA will produce quarterly progress reports and five technical reports. The technical 
reports  will  include  (i)  identification  of  approaches  to  increase  rural  infrastructure  climate 
resilience, and will contain the knowledge dissemination and communication strategy and action 
plan,  and  the  susceptibility–hazard–risk  prioritizing  framework; 17  (ii)  demonstration  site 
construction; (iii) training completion report; (iv) recommendations for the integration of the 
measures in training curricula, standard design procedures, and contract specifications; and (v) 
assessments of climate risk and vulnerability, with potential measures for strengthening the 
resilience of communities near the demonstrations.  
 
23.  The TA will have the initial responsibility for performance and deterioration monitoring 
and analysis of both the demonstration and control sites. Upon completion of the TA, MARD will 
continue the monitoring. MARD has identified the Viet Nam Academy for Water Resources’ 
Institute of Water and Environment as the preferred organization for long-term performance 
monitoring. 
 
24.  The knowledge dissemination and communication strategy will include such activities as 
field trips to the demonstration sites for government personnel, contractors, and interested 
private sector parties to view firsthand the demonstrations and their impact; and videos and 
slide shows will be produced to provide material for lectures on a range of approaches for in-
house training of key government personnel as well as related engineering schools, colleges, 
and institutes. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
25.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to the Government of Viet Nam to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Special Climate Change Fund of the Global Environment 
Facility for Promoting Climate Resilient Rural Infrastructure in Northern Mountain Provinces. 
                                                
16 This project will demonstrate techniques and approaches that have not hitherto been established in Viet Nam. 
There is not a record of previous experience to inform implementation. This introduces a level of uncertainty in 
predicting  input  to  output  relationships.  These  unallocated  consultant  inputs  will  be  utilized  to  address 
unpredictable implementation problems. 
17 UNDP will be coordinating the project outputs with the MARD provincial action plans for climate change.

Upon technical assistance completion, the equipment will be turned over to the executing agency.  
c Purpose: Technical assistance inception, progress, and final presentations; technical training courses for 
relevant decision makers, officials, consultants, contractors, and students. 
d This training will be carried out for counterparts, and contractors. It will include theoretical and practical 
aspects of survey, design, and implementation of relevant civil engineering and bioengineering works. It will 
cover such topics as the engineering properties of various indigenous plants, and methods for selecting and 
the application of the plants for soil and water conservation. 
e  Includes  terrain,  soils,  and  hydrology  mapping  for  the  susceptibility–hazard  assessments  of  selected 
subprojects.  
f    Implementation of the demonstrations by contractors. 
g  Tours carried out for the purpose of dissemination of the demonstration experience to stakeholders. These 
will be carried out at critical points in the project cycle such as at design, construction, and completion.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Team Leader and Bioengineering Specialist (14 person-months) 
1.    The  consultant  should  possess  a  master’s  degree  or  equivalent  in  engineering, 
agronomy, or a related discipline. They should have at least 15 years experience undertaking 
related  research,  demonstrating  or  providing  consulting  services  in  bioengineering.  The 
consultant  should  have  at  least  5  years  experience  in  rural  infrastructure  development  in 
developing countries in the humid tropics, preferably in countries with similar characteristics to 
the mountain areas of northern Viet Nam. Fluency in the English language is required. The team 
leader will: 
(i)  manage the consulting team, 
(ii)  liaise with government organizations at the central and provincial levels,  the 
  United  Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and other stakeholders; 
(iii)  formulate,  implement,  and  update  a  knowledge  dissemination  and 
  communication strategy and action plan; 
(iv)  carry out an orientation and training program for key staff; 
(v)  prepare the susceptibility–hazard–risk prioritizing framework; 
(vi)  design the demonstrations; 
(vii)  prepare the bid packages for the demonstrations and manage the tendering 
  process  according to Asian Development Bank (ADB) regulations;  
(viii)  supervise the implementation of the demonstrations; 
(ix)  monitor  the  results  of  the  demonstrations  and  determine  any  remedial  or 
  corrective work needed; 
(x)  prepare the quarterly reports, the five technical reports, and the final report; and 
(xi)  agree with the CPMU the documents that should be translated and arrange for 
  translation as required. 
 
2.  Climate Change Specialist (1 person-month) 
2.    The  consultant  should  possess  a  master’s  degree  or  equivalent  in  meteorology, 
environmental sciences, or a related discipline. They should have at least 10 years experience 
researching and/or documenting climate change effects, preferably in tropical countries, as well 
as disseminating information on climate change to the public, policy makers, and planners, 
preferably in developing countries. Fluency in the English language is required. The specialist 
will: 
(i)  assess and to the extent possible, quantify the likely climate change related 
trends in the areas of the demonstration sites; 
(ii)  identify the likely effects and impacts of climate change on rural infrastructure 
and current practices and techniques used to mitigate these effects; 
(iii)  provide input to the susceptibility-hazard-risk framework; and 
(iv)  provide input to the long-term demonstration monitoring framework for climatic 
information and analysis. 
 
  3.  Civil Engineer (3 person-months) 
3.     The consultant should possess a master’s degree or equivalent in civil or agricultural 
engineering or a related discipline. They should have at least 15 years experience in civil 
engineering in developing countries, with experience in the design and construction of rural 
infrastructure, including rural roads and water resources structures. They should have at least 
10  years’  experience  working  in  the  humid  tropics,  preferably  in  countries  with  similar 
environmental conditions to Viet Nam. The specialist will also, preferably, have had experience

Appendix 3     11 
working on projects that have used bioengineering techniques. Fluency in the English language 
is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  identify civil engineering techniques applicable within the context of the selected 
  subprojects; 
(ii)  provide input to the preparation of the susceptibility–hazard–risk framework; 
(iii)  provide input to the design of the demonstrations; 
(iv)  assist the team leader in supervising the implementation of the works;  
(v)  assist the team leader in documenting the results of the demonstrations from a 
  civil engineering (i.e., structure sustainability) point of view; and 
(vi)  draft construction technical specifications for consideration by the government. 
 
4.   Technical Trainer (2 person-months) 
4.    The consultant should possess a master’s degree or equivalent in engineering or a 
related  discipline,  with  formal  teaching/training  qualifications.  They  should  have  at  least 
15 years  experience  in  engineering  and  technical  training  in  developing  countries,  with 
experience  rural  infrastructure  and  bioengineering.  They  should  have  at  least  10  years 
experience working in the humid tropics, preferably in countries with similar environmental 
conditions to Viet Nam. Fluency in the English language is required. The specialist’s primary 
duty will be the design and implementation of the knowledge dissemination and communication 
strategy and action plan. The specialist will: 
(i)  assess the training needs for the use of appropriate technologies, 
(ii)  design the training modules, 
(iii)  carry out training of trainers courses for the national trainers, 
(iv)  supervise the implementation of the training and dissemination, and 
(v)  liaise with academic and training organizations. 
 
  5.  Geotechnical Engineer (1 person-month) 
5.    The  consultant  should  possess  a  master’s  degree  or  equivalent  in  geotechnical 
engineering  or  a  related  discipline.  They  should  have  at  least  15  years  experience  in 
geotechnical  engineering  in  developing  countries,  with  experience  in  the  design  and 
construction of roads and water resources structures. They should have at least 10 years 
experience working in the humid tropics, preferably in countries with similar environmental 
conditions to Viet Nam. The specialist will also, preferably, have had experience working on 
projects that have used bioengineering techniques. The specialist will: 
(i)  inspect the selected demonstration sites for any geotechnical issues that may 
  have a bearing on the design, and provide advice to the team leader accordingly; 
(ii)  provide input to the preparation of the susceptibility–hazard–risk framework; 
(iii)  provide input to the design of the demonstrations; and 
(iv)  assist the civil engineer to draft construction technical specifications. 
 
6.  Social Development Specialist (2 person-months) 
6.    The consultant should possess a master’s degree or equivalent in social sciences or a 
related discipline. They should have at least (i) 15 years experience in poverty and social 
development in developing countries, including rural infrastructure; and (ii) 5 years experience 
working in countries in Southeast Asia. The specialist should be familiar with ADB’s social and 
resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  safeguard  policies  and  guidelines.  They  will  identify, 
document, and implement measures to optimize the social benefits of the rural infrastructure 
climate resilience activities. Fluency in the English language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  review  and  provide  recommendations  regarding  the  Sustainable  Rural 
Infrastructure  Development  Project  in  Northern  Mountain  Provinces  (SRIDP) 
poverty and social assessment for the selected demonstration sites;

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(ii)  ensure the demonstrations conform to the SRIDP social safeguards; 
(iii)  prepare  a  work  plan  and  detailed  duties  for  the  national  gender  specialist, 
indigenous people specialist, and poverty specialist inputs; 
(iv)  identify  potential  gender-sensitive  social  benefits  and  opportunities  in  the 
demonstrations whereby disadvantaged groups can be included;  
(v)  design  and  implement  a  plan  to  integrate  social  inclusive  aspects  into  the 
demonstrations; 
(vi)  establish  monitoring  mechanisms  for  community  involvement  in  subproject 
implementation and long-term management; 
(vii)  document the results of the social inclusion process and make recommendations 
for future projects; and 
(viii)  consult  with  communities  near  the  demonstrations  on  how  to  improve  their 
climate change resilience based on the techniques demonstrated. 
 
7.  Unallocated (2 person-months) 
7.    Independent consultants are not included within the firm’s contract. This provision will be 
used for additional or supplemental inputs as needed during the course of implementation. 
Specific terms of reference will be prepared by ADB based on identified needs. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
  1.  Deputy Team Leader and Agricultural Engineer (34 person-months) 
8.    The  consultant  should  possess  an  undergraduate  degree  in  civil  or  agricultural 
engineering or a related discipline. They will have had at least 10 years experience in designing 
physical structures (roads, irrigation systems, water supply systems). Experience with slope 
stabilization, erosion prevention, and stream flow hydrology will be a valuable asset. Fluency in 
the English language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  Support the duties of the team leader, 
(ii)  Replace the team leader as necessary, 
(iii)  Carefully supervise the field teams, and 
(iv)  Carry out briefings and seminars as required. 
 
  2.  Agronomist and Forester (4 person-months) 
9.    The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in agronomy, forestry, or a 
related discipline. The agronomist/forester will have 10 years experience working with a variety 
of upland plant species, preferably undertaking research or implementation work aimed at 
erosion prevention, slope stabilization, or land rehabilitation. The specialist will be familiar with 
indigenous Vietnamese species as well as species from other parts of Southeast Asia that could 
be used for (i) erosion control, slope stabilization, and the protection of physical structures; and 
(ii) commercial production such as the production of traditional medicines, human food (such as 
herbs and spices), animal fodder, firewood, pulp and paper, or wood products. Fluency in the 
English language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  identify plant species best suited techniques being proposed, 
(ii)  determine  sustainable  sources  of  plants  and  other  materials  for  use  in  the 
demonstrations, 
(iii)  assist in the design of demonstration plots, 
(iv)  participate in the monitoring of demonstration sites and dissemination of results, 
and 
(v)  assist in the documentation of the results of the demonstrations.

Appendix 3     13 
  3.  Civil Engineer (5 person-months)  
10.    The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in civil engineering. They will 
have at least 10 years experience in the field of engineering, including the provision of rural 
infrastructure,  preferably  in  mountainous  areas.  Duties  will  be  similar  to  those  of  the 
international counterpart but the national consultant will be engaged for longer periods to ensure 
that civil engineering expertise is available when needed throughout the design and construction 
periods. Fluency in the English language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  identify civil engineering techniques applicable within the context of the selected 
subprojects, and present related technical information at the orientation program; 
(ii)  provide input to the design of the demonstrations; and 
(iii)  assist with the drafting of construction technical specifications for consideration 
by the government. 
 
4.     Geotechnical Engineer (2 person-months)     
11.    The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in geotechnical engineering or 
a related discipline. They will have at least 10 years experience in geotechnical engineering, 
with  experience  in  mountainous  areas.  Duties  will  be  similar  to  those  of  the  international 
counterpart  but  the  national  consultant  will  be  engaged  for  longer  periods  to  ensure  that 
geotechnical  engineering  expertise  is  available  when  needed  throughout  the  design  and 
construction periods. Fluency in the English language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  assist in the inspection of the selected demonstration sites for any geotechnical 
issues that may have a bearing on the design,  
(ii)  provide input to the design of the demonstrations, and 
(iii)  assist in the drafting of construction technical specifications for consideration by 
the government. 
 
5.  Technical Trainer (4 person-months) 
12.    The  consultant  should  possess  an  undergraduate  degree  in  civil  or  agricultural 
engineering or a related discipline, with formal qualifications in teaching and training. They 
should have at least 8 years experience in engineering and technical training, including rural 
infrastructure civil and bioengineering. Fluency in the English language is required. The national 
trainer will assist the international trainer to carry out his/her duties (para. 4). 
 
  6.    Meteorologist and Hydrologist (2 person-months) 
13.    The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in meteorology, hydrology, or 
a related discipline. They should have 5 years experience in measuring climate and stream 
flows and be familiar with the sources of historical climate data and hydrological data as well as 
the current technology used for climatic and hydrological measurements. Experience in the 
mountainous areas of Viet Nam is preferable. Fluency in the English language is required. The 
expert will: 
(i)  assist the international climate change specialist to determine and gather the 
types of data to be recorded that will best reflect the impact of climate change in 
the SRIDP project areas; and 
(ii)  document extreme events (typhoons, floods) and examine the impact of these 
events on the demonstrations and the degree to which the  structures being 
protected withstood them.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
7.  Gender Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
14.   The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in the social sciences or a 
related discipline. They should have at least 7 years experience in poverty and gender analysis, 
with experience in rural infrastructure. The specialist should be familiar with ADB’s gender and 
social safeguard policies and guidelines. They will assist the international social development 
specialist to carry out their duties (para. 6). The international social development specialist will 
prepare a detailed work plan for the inputs. Fluency in the English language is required. The 
specialist will: 
(i)  supervise the demonstrations for conformity to the SRIDP gender action plan, 
(ii)  supervise implementation of the plan to integrate social inclusive aspects into the 
demonstrations, 
(iii)  monitor  community  involvement  with  respect  to  gender  in  subproject 
implementation and long-term management, and 
(iv)  consult with communities near the demonstrations on how to improve the climate 
change resilience of their communities based on the techniques demonstrated. 
   
8.  Indigenous People Specialist (1 person-month)  
15.   The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in the social sciences or a 
related discipline. They should have at least 7 years experience in poverty and indigenous 
peoples development, with experience in rural infrastructure. The specialist should be familiar 
with ADB’s indigenous peoples social safeguard policies and guidelines. They will assist the 
international social development specialist to carry out her/his duties (para. 6). The international 
social development specialist will prepare a detailed work plan for the inputs. Fluency in the 
English language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  supervise the demonstrations for conformity to the SRIDP indigenous people’s 
framework and ADB safeguards, 
(ii)  supervise implementation of the plan to integrate the social inclusive aspects with 
respect to indigenous people into the demonstrations, 
(iii)  monitor  community  involvement  in  subproject  implementation  and  long-term 
management, and 
(iv)  consult with communities near the demonstrations on how to improve the climate 
change resilience of their communities based on the techniques demonstrated. 
 
  9.  Poverty Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
16.   The consultant should possess an undergraduate degree in the social sciences or a 
related discipline. They should have at least 7 years experience in poverty analysis, including 
rural infrastructure. The specialist should be familiar with ADB’s gender and social safeguards 
policies and guidelines. They will assist the international social development specialist to carry 
out  her/his  duties  (para.  6)  within  their  respective  disciplines.  The  international  social 
development specialist will prepare a detailed work plan for their inputs. Fluency in the English 
language is required. The specialist will: 
(i)  supervise the demonstrations for conformity to the SRIDP social safeguards, 
(ii)  supervise implementation of the plan to integrate the social inclusive aspects into 
the demonstrations, 
(iii)  monitor  community  involvement  in  subproject  implementation  and  long-term 
management, and 
(iv)  consult with communities near the demonstrations on how improve their climate 
change resilience based on the techniques demonstrated.
